contentItem.text: Orcas are also called Killer whales and live in family groups called pods. Sometimes up to 40 individuals live in a pod. Members of the pod make distinctive calls that only other members of their pod will recognize. They use these calls to send messages, to find each other in the dark and over long distances!
Orcas are one of the world most powerful predators! They have teeth up to 4 inches (10 centimeters) long and can grab seals right off the ice. Orcas eat seals, sea lions, and even other whales.
Orcas live in the cold, costal waters from the polar regions to the equator!

Healthy adult Orcas don't have any natural predators, but some species of sharks prey on young or sick whales. Orcas are protective of their young and sisters will help mothers protect the young from predators.

Orcas live in both resident and transient pods. Resident pods stay in the same waters and prefer to eat fish. Transient pods join and break apart as whales travel through waters around the world. Transient pods prefer to eat marine mammals. Even though they are called killer whales they are actually the largest members of the dolphin family!
